column4: I want to find out how much memory a process is consuming. Using ps -eopid,%mem,cmd I can find out the percentage; is there any way to find the actual amount? A program hangs my Ubuntu bcz of memory leak so I want a shell script to keep on running to check whether the memory crosses the max amount I assign. If it does in that case it should kill it. Also if someone knows of a better solution please let me know. Thank you in advance
ty, but there is a strange value returned by pmap
the ps %mem shows 5.9% which is 120MB of 2GB
pmap may be included libraries, im not quite sure how it works.  also, mem includes /swap if i'm not mistaken
you could always multiply %mem by total
http://mail.gnome.org/archives/gnome-list/1999-April/msg02337.html  - long story short - ps -faux, use numbers under rss for best estimate
